author: peter.davies
content:
I think you need some perspective on what we are actually doing here. We are asking participants to generate a private ECDSA key `s`, publish the public keys of `[s, s^2, s^3, ..., s^n]`, and then discard the private key `s`. We then perform BLS signature aggregation to create an aggregated public key (the aggregation is actually considerably more complicated but conceptually the same).
We have a mathematical proof that this is secure relying that:
a) Elliptic Curve Cryptography is not busted. (Technically the security assumption is slightly weaker than the one needed for ECDSA, but we can be confident that all ECC will rapidly ditched by everyone if it is broken).
b) At least one of the participants is honest (i.e generates a truly random private key `s` randomly and then discards it).

author: peter.davies
content: Your objection seems to be that you believe that honest people are incapable of generating random cryptographic keys, in which case mass large scale hacking of Ethereum wallets is possible and all of cryptography is broken.
